title: JupyterCon 2018
summary:
Meet the Anaconda team at JupyterCon 2018, taking place in NYC on August 21-24. We'll be at booth #14!

In addition, on Friday, August 24, Anaconda's Damián Avila (co-winner of the 2017 ACM Software System Award for his work on Jupyter!) will deliver a presentation on RISE, which in recent years has evolved into the main slideshow machinery for live presentations within the Jupyter notebook. Damián will explain not only how to install and use RISE, but also how to customize it for nice, styled presentations. He will demonstrate how to get PDFs from your slides, how to use RISE with the nbextension_configurator package, and how to use the new chalkboard capabilities.

Presentation: Current RISE candies and its evolution into the future
Presenter: Damián Avila
Friday, August 24
5:00 – 5:40 PM
Location: Beekman/Sutton North

title: Strata NYC 2018
summary:
Headed to Strata NYC on September 11-13? We are, too!

On Tuesday, September 11, join Senior Solutions Architect James Bednar for a tutorial on Making Interactive Browser-Based Visualizations Easy in Python. While Python lets you solve data-science problems by stitching together packages from the Python ecosystem, it can be difficult to assemble the right tools to solve real-world problems. James will demonstrate how to use the 15+ packages covered by the new PyViz.org initiative to make it simple to build interactive plots and dashboards, even for large, streaming, and highly multidimensional data.

Tutorial: Making Interactive Browser-Based Visualizations Easy in Python
Presenter: James Bednar
Tuesday, September 11
9:00 AM - 12:30 PM
Room 1E 06

On Wednesday, September 12, SVP of Products & Marketing Mathew Lodge will present Conda, Docker & Kubernetes: The Cloud-Native Future of Data Science. Big data architectures like Hadoop and Spark solve the distributed database problem, but assume your code is written in Java or another JVM-based language like Scala. However, data science, predictive analytics, and machine learning don’t happen in JVM-based languages—they happen in Python, R, and, to a lesser extent, C/C++. Furthermore, all the major players like AWS, Microsoft, Google, IBM, Red Hat, and Docker are lined up behind Kubernetes. Containers and Kubernetes make great language-agnostic distributed computing clusters, as it is just as easy to deploy Python as it is Java. This talk will show you how.

Talk: Conda, Docker & Kubernetes: The Cloud-Native Future of Data Science
Presenter: Mathew Lodge
Wednesday, September 12
2:55 - 3:35 PM
Room 1A 03

title: Minds Mastering Machines (M³): The ML and AI Conference
summary:
M³ brings together experts in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data science to review the latest tools and frameworks and share best practices for getting up and running with AI/ML projects. This year's conference will be held in London on 15-17 October 2018.

On 16 October, Stan Seibert, who leads the Community Innovation team at Anaconda, will present "Accelerating Deep Learning with GPUs." Stan will cover how to install and deploy GPU accelerated code using Anaconda, and demonstrate how to combine the most popular deep learning frameworks with Python packages to power data science experiments and production deployments.

Talk: Accelerating Deep Learning with GPUs
Presenter: Stan Seibert
Tuesday, 16 October 2018
4:30-5:15 PM

title: NVIDIA GPU Technology Conference
summary:
Experts from NVIDIA and other leading AI and deep learning organizations will convene in Washington, DC on 22-24 October 2018 for NVIDIA’s GPU Technology Conference (GTC). Stan Seibert, Anaconda Director of Community Innovation, will present "Turbocharging the AI Pipeline with Python and Anaconda."

The rise of GPU-accelerated data science and AI has come about through a combination of open source innovation and better tooling to support reproducible workflows. However, as the diverse array of deep learning libraries continue to mature, attention is moving to other parts of the AI pipeline, including simulation, ETL, and deployment.

In this talk, Stan will review OS projects that address these other areas—such as Numba, for implementing custom simulations and data transformations on the GPU, and PyGDF, for GPU accelerated dataframes. He then will discuss how the Anaconda Distribution and its conda packaging system help data scientists create reproducible environments and deploy models. Finally, he'll talk about how Anaconda Enterprise allows data science teams to collaborate efficiently on GPU-accelerated projects with each other, and supports AI workflows from data exploration all the way to deployment.
